In addition to the code above, you can add more interactive elements to the chart, such as a button to reset the alarm and hide the draggable line. Here is an example of how you can do this:
```
import dash
import dash_core_components as dcc
import dash_html_components as html
import pandas as pd
import plotly.graph_objects as go
from dash.dependencies import Input, Output, State

app = dash.Dash()

# define callback function
def update_chart(n_interval):
    # fetch updated stock data
    df = pd.read_csv('stock_data.csv')

    # update chart with new data
    chart = dcc.Graph(id='stock-chart', figure={
        'data': [go.Candlestick(
            x=df['date'],
            open=df['open'],
            high=df['high'],
            low=df['low'],
            close=df['close']
        )]
    })

    return chart

app.layout = html.Div([
    # add a range slider to select the time range
    dcc.RangeSlider(
        id='time-range',
        min=0,
        max=len(df),
        value=[0, len(df)],
        marks={i: df.loc[i, 'date'] for i in range(0, len(df), 100)}
    ),
    # add a div to display the alarm message
    html.Div(id='alarm-message'),
    html.Div(id='chart-container'),
    # add a reset button
    html.Button(id='reset-button', children='Reset Alarm')
])

# specify the callback function

    [Output('chart-container', 'children'), Output('alarm-message', 'children')],
```
